intro: Pochota pseudofaroensis, commonly known as the Andean pison, is a member of the Malvaceae family and is native to the highlands of South America. It is a shrub or small tree that can grow up to 5 meters in height, characterized by its dense, woody structure. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that are clustered in inflorescences, followed by capsule fruits containing numerous seeds. Its leaves are typically elliptical with a rough texture and are arranged alternately along the stems. Pochota pseudofaroensis is adapted to harsh, high-altitude environments and is often found in cloud forests.
